metadata.case_name: Kamlaprasad Khetan and Ishwari Khetan Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Union of India

facts.text: Ishwari Khetan Sugar Mills Ltd. is a public limited company where four branches of Khetan family held large number of shares, about one-fourth held by outsiders. Managed by firm of Managing Agents consisting of four Khetan family members including Kedar Nath Khetan and Onkarmal Khetan (father of petitioner No.1).
Managing Agents also managed Maheshwari Khetan Sugar Mills Ltd., Morarji Gokuldas Spinning and Weaving Mills, Bombay, and Laxmidevi Sugar Mills Ltd., Deoria.

Trouble arose in 1950-51 when Onkarmal Khetan allegedly withdrew large sums from accounts, leading to suits against him. Onkarmal retaliated with suits for receiver, restraining general meetings, obstructive proceedings.
Petitioners alleged that balance sheet for 1950-51 (published June 1952) showed Directors including authorised Controller utilised company funds for personal gain, breached Companies Act.

Suit No. 4 of 1952 filed by petitioners against Directors including authorised Controller for permanent injunction restraining exercise of powers as Directors and declaration that notice for 24th ordinary general meeting on July 9, 1952 was illegal. Ex-parte injunction on July 8, 1952, vacated as without jurisdiction; fresh injunction on June 3, 1953, confirmed by Allahabad High Court on September 14, 1953.
24th ordinary general meeting held July 9, 1952; shareholders unanimously approved Directors' report and audited balance sheet as on October 9, 1951.
Extraordinary general meeting on November 9, 1953 by shareholders re-elected authorised Controller and others as Directors, subject to court decision in Suit No.4/1952.
Suit No.4/1952 still pending as of July 31, 1956; petitioner No.1 obtained ex-parte adjournment.

Ministry of Food communication November 8, 1952: differences likely to cause fall in sugar production, detrimental to consumers, cane growers, workers; threatened investigation/management takeover for both Ishwari and Maheshwari mills.
Order under s.3(4) Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act, 1946 on December 18, 1952: authorised Controller given certain control functions over Ishwari Khetan Sugar Mills.
Onkarmal filed writ petition against December 18, 1952 order; Court expedited hearing, directed periodic audit; petition dismissed May 14, 1954 as infructuous.
Order under s.15 IDRA July 30, 1953: appointed three persons to investigate several mills including Ishwari Khetan.
Order under s.18A IDRA November 14, 1953: authorised Controller to take over management for one year.
IDRA amended by Act 26 of 1953 inserting Chapter IIIA with s.18A.
Supreme Court decision in Dwarkadas Shrinivas v. Sholapur Spinning (1954 SCR 674) on Art.31(2).
Central Government cancelled all s.18A appointments May 21, 1954; management vested back in owner.
Authorised Controller allegedly continued in possession post-cancellation.
Order under Essential Supplies Act July 16, 1954: authorised Controller given control functions.
Second s.15 investigation September 19, 1954 by panel; recommended takeover for three years.
Petitioners filed writ petition against July 16, 1954 order on January 31, 1955; amended to challenge subsequent orders.
Impugned order November 8, 1955 under s.18A: authorised Kedar Nath Khetan as Controller for one year, cancelling July 16, 1954 order.
Amending order November 7, 1956: substituted 'two years' for 'one year'.
Court permitted authorised Controller to intervene October 1, 1956.
Mill earned profit in 1953-54; likely Rs.84,321 profit in 1954-55.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order dated November 8, 1955 under s.18A IDRA fulfilled essential requirements: investigation under s.15 and opinion of mismanagement highly detrimental to industry/public interest.
Whether s.18A IDRA or s.21 General Clauses Act authorised extension of period from one year to two years by amending order dated November 7, 1956.
Whether the orders were bona fide, given appointment of Kedar Nath Khetan who was party to dispute, subject to injunction, alleged breaches.

petitioner_arguments.text: Order November 8, 1955 invalid as did not fulfill s.18A(1)(b) requirements: no rational opinion of mismanagement possible as authorised Controller was in charge from Dec 1952 to Nov 1955 (with short break).
Amending order November 7, 1956 invalid as s.18A does not authorise extension; does not comply with s.21 General Clauses Act requirements; proviso to s.18A(2) inapplicable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.18A(2) proviso IDRA; s.21 General Clauses Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Orders not bona fide: appointed Kedar Nath Khetan, mismanaging party to dispute, against whom injunction, ceased to be Director due to breaches, income-tax issues.

respondent_arguments.text: Ongoing family disputes, litigation caused potential stoppage, fall in production detrimental to public interest; s.15 investigations (1953,1954) and recommendations supported opinion.
Distinction between control functions under Essential Supplies Act and full management takeover under s.18A; post-cancellation May 1954, management back with quarreling owners.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.3(4) Essential Supplies Act; s.18A, s.18B, s.18F IDRA

respondent_arguments.text: Amending order valid under s.21 General Clauses Act, exercisable in like manner/conditions; conditions (s.15 investigation, mismanagement) relate to period when vested in owner.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.21 General Clauses Act; s.18A IDRA

respondent_arguments.text: Appointment of experienced Kedar Nath suitable; no ulterior purpose shown.

court_reasoning.text: s.18A(1)(b) requirements fulfilled: s.15 investigations done; opinion of detrimental management rational due to ongoing disputes/litigation even under partial control orders; full takeover necessary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Crux was inter se disputes among Directors/Managing Agents leading to protracted litigation; materials existed for opinion.

court_reasoning.text: Conditions of s.18A(1)(b) (s.15 investigation, mismanagement) relate to period when management vested in owner; amendment under s.21 valid as conditions continued post-original order, no fresh vesting in owner.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power to amend exercisable subject to like conditions; not static or requiring re-fulfillment during Controller's management.

court_reasoning.text: Bona fides: Selection of experienced person open to Government; no evidence of ulterior purpose beyond statutory objects.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Test is not better person available, but whether for ulterior purpose.

court_reasoning.text: Sarkar J. concurs except on amendment: s.21 conditions are those order subject to (e.g., max 5 years), not jurisdictional pre-conditions for issuing order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amendment not requiring re-fulfillment of s.18A(1)(b) as that would make s.21 redundant.

holdings.text: Orders dated November 8, 1955 and November 7, 1956 valid under s.18A IDRA and s.21 General Clauses Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dwarkadas Shrinivas of Bombay v. The Sholapur Spinning Weaving Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Pronounced on Art.31(2) validity of Sholapur Ordinance/Act; led to cancellation of s.18A appointments.

precedents_cited.case_name: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. v. Gutta Mill Workers Union
precedents_cited.relevance: No power to extend time retrospectively under General Clauses Act where functus officio; distinguished as rule of construction depends on context.

statutes_cited.name: Industries (Development and Regulation) Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for investigations, takeover of management, distinction from control functions, vesting on cancellation; Chapter IIIA inserted 1953 protected by Ninth Schedule.

statutes_cited.name: Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Orders granting control functions, distinguished from full management takeover.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to amend orders exercisable in like manner/conditions; conditions relate to owner's management period.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition for enforcement of fundamental rights; s.18A not challengeable.

outcome.summary: Petition under Art.32 dismissed; orders upheld as valid; no violation of fundamental rights. Preliminary objection on locus not decided as suit pending.
outcome.costs: Costs in favour of respondent Union of India; authorised Controller bears own costs.

key_quotes.text: "the Central Government might reasonably have felt that the order dated July 16, 1954, which vested certain functions of control only, was not enough to meet the situation and a more drastic step was necessary."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains basis for s.18A opinion despite prior controls.

key_quotes.text: "the two conditions, one as to an investigation under s.15 and the other as to mismanagement, relate to a period when the management of the industrial undertaking is legally vested in its owner"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to validity of amendment under s.21.

key_quotes.text: "The test to be applied is whether the appointment was made for some ulterior purpose, some purpose other than the object for which the law... was enacted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
